About Contact us News Features Business Insight Comment Sports Contact us Muckracker Africa Entertainment Local News Contact us About Breaking Kamoli says goodbye Comrades, I‚Äôm going nowhere! Mofomobe demands ‚Äòhis freedom‚Äô Objection! My Lord! Lesotho‚Äôs women solar technicians Mutiny suspects in limbo From Beijing with love! Driving change, brick by brick! Police probe doctor‚Äôs death Coalition youths split Home / World / Samsung kills off Galaxy Note 7 smartphone Samsung kills off Galaxy Note 7 smartphone By The Post Tweet Pin It Updated: October 14, 2016 By¬†CHOE SANG-HUN ¬≠SEOUL, South Korea ‚Äî Samsung Electronics is killing its troubled Galaxy Note 7 smartphone, a humbling about-face for the South Korean giant and its global brand. In an unprecedented move, the company will no longer produce or market the smartphones. The demise of the Galaxy Note 7 is a major setback for Samsung, the world‚Äôs largest maker of smartphones. The premium device ‚Äî with a 5.7-inch screen, curved contours and comparatively high price ‚Äî won praise from consumers and reviewers, and was the company‚Äôs most ambitious effort yet to take on Apple for the high-end market. But Samsung has struggled to address reports that the Galaxy Note 7 could overheat and catch fire because of a manufacturing flaw. Last month, the company said it would recall 2.5 million phones to fix the problem. But in recent days, Galaxy Note 7 users emerged with reports that some devices that had supposedly been repaired were overheating, smoking and even bursting into flames. And on Monday, Samsung asked Note 7 customers to power off the phones while it worked on the problem. In a statement filed with the South Korean stock exchange late Tuesday, Samsung said it had made a ‚Äúfinal decision‚Äù to stop production. The company will no longer make or market the phones, said a person familiar with the decision, who spoke on the condition of anonymity because Samsung did not publicly disclose details. Samsung has a strong position in modestly priced smartphones and has made progress in challenging the Apple iPhone for the high end of the market. Samsung showed its confidence in the new Galaxy Note 7 by skipping a sixth version in the series and offering the new phone beginning in August, before Apple‚Äôs introduction of its iPhone 7. It was unclear where the Galaxy Note 7‚Äôs problem began. But Samsung‚Äôs fight to catch up with Apple by cramming increasingly sophisticated features into the device may have been the phone‚Äôs undoing. Industry experts are scrutinizing Samsung‚Äôs supply chain to see whether the rush to market caused technical problems or led to corners being cut. ‚ÄúWith the Note 7, Samsung strengthened its power as a speedy competitor,‚Äù said Lee Seung-woo, an analyst with IBK Investment & Securities. ‚ÄúBut one wonders whether it hasn‚Äôt raced ahead alone, without helping its component suppliers to catch up.‚Äù The company is facing an immediate, and substantial, financial blow. On Tuesday, even before Samsung had announced it was killing the Galaxy Note 7, its¬†South Korea-traded shares fell more than eight percent, its biggest daily drop since 2008, knocking US$17 billion off the company‚Äôs market value. Strategy Analytics, a research firm, had earlier estimated that Samsung could lose more than US$10 billion from the phone‚Äôs troubles. Samsung‚Äôs smartphone business also helps its other divisions by buying their computer chips and panel screens. Tougher to predict is how badly the Samsung brand itself will suffer. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs difficult to estimate now the damage it has caused to Samsung‚Äôs mid- and long-term brand value,‚Äù Mr. Lee said, ‚Äúas well as its impact on Samsung‚Äôs smartphone sales in the future.‚Äù An editorial in South Korea‚Äôs largest newspaper, the Chosun Ilbo, said: ‚ÄúYou cannot really calculate the loss of consumer trust in money.‚Äô‚Äô It said that Samsung must realize that it ‚Äúdidn‚Äôt take many years for Nokia to tumble from its position as the world‚Äôs top cellphone maker.‚Äù No major manufacturer has killed off such a high-profile smartphone at the height of its popularity. But the person familiar with Samsung‚Äôs decision to terminate production said that the company had determined that simply removing the Galaxy Note 7 from the market would be the quickest way to stem further confusion and anxiety about the phone, albeit a costly one. It is an embarrassing moment for Samsung, whose name has come to be synonymous among South Koreans with cutting-edge technology and manufacturing prowess. The Galaxy Note 7 was one of the most ambitious products Samsung had begun marketing under the leadership of Vice Chairman Lee Jae-yong, who took the helm of the country‚Äôs largest family controlled conglomerate, or chaebol, after his father, Chairman Lee Kun-hee, became ill in 2014. The senior Mr. Lee, who has not been seen in public since, famously burned a pile of 150 000 defective Samsung phones 21 years ago to demonstrate the company‚Äôs commitment to quality. Initially, Samsung watchers credited Lee Jae-yong ‚Äî also known as Jay Y. Lee ‚Äî with acting with similar decisiveness when Samsung first recalled the 2.5 million Galaxy Note 7 devices. But as the phone‚Äôs problems lingered, scrutiny intensified. The troubling part for many is that Samsung recalled the devices, but then had to try to fix the problem a second time. ‚ÄúMaybe they should look harder and closer at what is happening at the management level,‚Äù said Roberta Cozza, a research director with Gartner Research, who cited the damage to Samsung‚Äôs credibility with customers and with telecommunications carriers. Earlier on Tuesday, the Korean Agency for Technology and Standards, a government organization, recommended that Samsung stop selling the device, saying that it had enough reason to believe the replacement model also had a ‚Äúpossible defect.‚Äù The agency did not provide details. The government also ordered South Korean airlines not to accept Galaxy Note 7 phones in luggage and to ensure that those who carry them on board powered them down. Just hours before the Galaxy Note 7‚Äôs demise, Samsung said it would stop selling the model around the world, essentially pulling it from the market as it sought to determine what had caused the fires. It said it had asked telecom carriers and retailers globally to stop sales and exchanges of the device. Samsung had also asked all consumers with original Galaxy Note 7s or replacement models to power them down and to stop using them while the company worked with regulators to solve the problem. Just a few hours before that, Samsung said it had temporarily halted production of the Galaxy Note 7 to try to fix the problem. In South Korea, the company apologized to consumers and business partners, while mobile carriers offered refunds to owners of the phones or allowed them switch to other Samsung models. The decision to end production came on the same day that the recall spread to China. Samsung had said earlier that models sold in China contained batteries that were different from those that had caught fire. But on Tuesday, before it announced the end of the Galaxy Note 7, Samsung said it was recalling nearly 191 000 of the devices in China. That did not go over well with many Chinese consumers. ‚ÄúSamsung‚Äôs Galaxy Note 7 explodes, and they recall their phones in every other country except for China. They really look down on us,‚Äù¬†wrote¬†one user on Weibo, a Chinese social media platform.¬† ‚Äì New York Times ‚Üê Previous Story Saudi Arabia admits defeat Next Story ‚Üí The problem with referendums Leave a Reply Cancel reply Your email address will not be published. Required fields are marked * Comment Name * Email * Website Currently you have JavaScript disabled. Home Industry Tech Google Pixel XL: Real, direct competition to the Apple iPhone¬†7 Google Pixel XL: Real, direct competition to the Apple iPhone¬†7 When Google launched artificial intelligence (AI)-powered premium devices Pixel and Pixel XL earlier this month, the message was clear: The device with the personal Google Assistant built right in sounded the threat bugle for Apple iPhone 7 and 7 Plus. By: IANS | New Delhi | Published: October 21, 2016 12:45 PM The comparison is natural, especially in the absence of another flagship device, the Samsung Galaxy Note 7, which leaves Google and Apple fighting for the premium segment. (Reuters) When Google launched artificial intelligence (AI)-powered premium devices Pixel and Pixel XL earlier this month, the message was clear: The device with the personal Google Assistant built right in sounded the threat bugle for Apple iPhone 7 and 7 Plus. The comparison is natural, especially in the absence of another flagship device, the Samsung Galaxy Note 7, which leaves Google and Apple fighting for the premium segment. Google has been synonymous with innovation. This time, with a brand new Android OS Nougat and Google Assistant, Pixel devices are set to counter Apple‚Äôs iOS 10 and intelligent assistant Siri. Let us see what the 5.5-inch Pixel XL (32GB, black colour) has for Indian consumers who are searching for a premium smartphone. The aluminum and glass-built device looks elegant and fits comfortably in the palm. Unlike Nexus 6P, which had a thin glass strip at the top, Pixel XL‚Äôs back panel has almost one-third glass covering. Putting an end to Android users‚Äô long wait, the Google Assistant in Pixel XL definitely has an edge over Apple‚Äôs Siri. See for yourself. When asked, :Are you a man or a woman?‚Äù, Google Assistant responded with answers like ‚ÄúI‚Äôm all inclusive :D‚Äù and ‚ÄúDoes it really matter?‚Äù while Siri staidly replied: ‚ÄúI was not assigned a gender.‚Äù To ‚ÄúWho will win the US presidential election?‚Äù Google Assistant displayed poll results by the New York Times, The Telegraph and Independent while Siri returned Wikipedia and Quora with an iOS 10-powered iPhone. While searching restaurants near our office, Google Assistant displayed food joints as close as 300 metres while Siri said that the nearest restaurant is 600 metres away. To further test its intelligence, Google Assistant was asked, ‚ÄúWho is Siri?‚Äù It explained, ‚ÄúSiri is Apple‚Äôs intelligent assistant. She is very witty.‚Äù Siri, however, was more informative than Google Assistant when asked ‚ÄúWho is the Prime Minister of India?‚Äù. While Siri threw up results like when Narendra Modi became the Prime Minister and how long has he been serving, Google Assistant came back only with his name. Google Assistant can tell jokes, remember your passwords and even set the alarm for you in a clear voice. The ‚ÄúPixel Imprint‚Äù fingerprint scanner is located at the back and is extremely responsive. It not only unlocked the device in a split second but also accepted (authorised) half a fingerprint for unlocking. While lock and volume up/down buttons are on the right of the Corning Gorilla Glass 4 protected AMOLED display, a nano-SIM slot sits at the left bumper of the device. Google has retained Type-C charging port that charged the 3,450 mAh battery in a flat 48 minutes. The device with Qualcomm‚Äôs latest Snapdragon 821 Quad core processor and 4GB DDR4 RAM will get first updates and free unlimited cloud space is not to be missed. Google has put in a lot of accessories inside the box, including a two-way Type-C port cable ensuring OTG device (also included) support. With this cable, one can charge Pixel XL with another phone having a Type-C port. The smartphone runs like a charm on Android Nougat 7.1 ‚Äî the only device till date to have it. The apps explorer icon is replaced by a pull-up App Drawer which is more convenient. A swipe right on the screen brings the notable search results in line with browsing history. When we swiped right, information about the FC Barcelona vs Manchester City football match; updates about the Indian Soccer League tournament; and scores for the India vs New Zealand One-Day cricket match popped up. Pixel‚Äôs 12.3MP rear camera with f/2.0 has been rated the highest ever 89 DxOMark Mobile score. It is very fast, responsive and has a video stabilising mode. As expected, the photos in broad daylight were stunning. Even in ‚Äúvery low light conditions‚Äù, the camera did not disappoint. Under natural light at¬†7 pm, the photos clicked without flash had clarity and little grains while the photo taken with flash were sharper. As compared to shooting video in normal mode, we noticed a remarkable difference when we shot the same video with ‚ÄúVideo Stabilisation‚Äù on. There were low or no jerks and no picture distortion. The 8MP camera works fine and while using it with Google‚Äôs video calling app Duo, the receiver gets a sharper image (as compared to the Nexus 6P). One can even try new gestures, relish the audio output and save unlimited data online in original quality for free. What doesn‚Äôt work? Pixel devices are not waterproof. At a time when Samsung Galaxy S7 Edge (and the now discontinued Galaxy Note 7) and Apple are offering IP68 rating (waterproof ratings), Pixel smartphones fall behind in this category. The camera does not have an optical image stabilisation feature and the Type-C to Type-C charging is slow. Conclusion: If you think about shelling out Rs 72,000 for the 32GB variant of iPhone 7 Plus, consider Google Pixel XL for Rs 67,000 as your date with Google Assistant will floor you without any doubt. It not only unlocked the device in a split second but also accepted (authorised) half a fingerprint for unlocking. While lock and volume up/down buttons are on the right of the Corning Gorilla Glass 4 protected AMOLED display, a nano-SIM slot sits at the left bumper of the device. Google has retained Type-C charging port that charged the 3450 mAh battery in a flat 48 minutes. The device with Qualcomm's latest Snapdragon 821 Quad core processor and 4GB DDR4 RAM will get first updates and free unlimited cloud space is not to be missed. Google has put in a lot of accessories inside the box, including a two-way Type-C port cable ensuring OTG device (also included) support. With this cable, one can charge Pixel XL with another phone having a Type-C port. The smartphone runs like a charm on Android Nougat 7.1 - the only device till date to have it. As compared to shooting video in normal mode, we noticed a remarkable difference when we shot the same video with "Video Stabilisation" on. There were low or no jerks and no picture distortion. The 8MP camera works fine and while using it with Google's video calling app Duo, the receiver gets a sharper image (as compared to the Nexus 6P). One can even try new gestures, relish the audio output and save unlimited data online in original quality for free. What doesn't work? Pixel devices are not waterproof. The camera does not have an optical image stabilisation feature and the Type-C to Type-C charging is slow. Conclusion: If you think about shelling out Rs 72000 for the 32GB variant of iPhone 7 Plus, consider Google Pixel XL for Rs 67000 as your date with Google Assistant will floor you without any doubt. News Sports Entertainment Life Obits E-Edition Autos Jobs Real Estate Classifieds Site Archive Prep Boys Volleyball: Warriors wrap up season sweep of Knights Thursday Oct¬†20,¬†2016¬†at¬†12:01¬†AM Oct¬†20,¬†2016¬†at¬†11:07¬†PM Matthew Peters Staff Writer @DP_MattPeters APPLE VALLEY ‚Äî Life as the lone boys volleyball team in the High Desert was, well, lonely for Apple Valley Christian. That‚Äôs not a problem anymore. With Academy for Academic Excellence adding a program this season the short trips were nice. And getting three wins was even nicer. Apple Valley Christian (10-5) finished the season sweep against AAE with a three-set victory (25-20, 25-20, 25-23) on Thursday evening at the James Wood Community Center. Apple Valley Christian dropped just one set to AAE all year. Both teams begin the Inland Coast League post-season tournament on Tuesday. Apple Valley Christian finished the year in third place in the league while AAE is fifth. Apple Valley Christian coach John Richart said almost all road trips required a minimum drive of an hour and 15 minutes before AAE arrived. Now they have a team just across town to play. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve been coaching off and on for like 16 years and we‚Äôve never had a local team,‚Äù Richart said. ‚ÄúIt was great to have an away game that was just across town. ‚ÄúThey improved a lot as well. They are a scrappy team. They are going to have a great future in the league, I can see that. They work hard. A lot of improvement.‚Äù AAE coach Emily Gruver, just one year removed from playing volleyball on the AAE girls team, took a bunch of basketball and baseball players and helped the team get better along the way, finishing 5-15. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs been fun,‚Äù Gruver said. ‚ÄúThere was a lot that I had to learn that I didn‚Äôt know, but teaching wise it‚Äôs the same.‚Äù Although they were swept Thursday, the Knights made it a difficult match for the Warriors at times. AAE had leads late in the both the second and third sets only to watch those slip away. AAE had a 17-12 lead in the second set and then a 22-20 lead late the third set before dropping both. Richart said Thursday‚Äôs match wasn‚Äôt his squad‚Äôs most focused effort, and that can sometimes be a trend with his Warriors. ‚ÄúThe blessing and the curse of my team is a lot of these guys have been with each other since kindergarten, from a very young age,‚Äù Richart said. ‚ÄúThey are like a bunch of brothers. So they goof around and play loose, and that‚Äôs great. But then they goof around and play loose and that‚Äôs not great. So that all depends.‚Äù Josh Berry led Apple Valley Christian with 11 kills, 15 blocks and two aces; Khahn Messner had eight kills and four aces; Noah Leslie added four kills and 12 assists; and Alex Richart had three kills, five assists and two block. Richart said the team had aspirations for a second-place finish in league but will now try to take the title in the league‚Äôs post-season tournament. With five seniors this is one of the best Apple Valley Christian squads in recent history, Richart said. ‚ÄúIt will be a tough road but I think the guys will be up for the challenge,‚Äù Richart said. Matthew Peters can be reached at 760-955-5365 or mpeters@vvdailypress.com. You can also follow him on Twitter @DP_MattPeters. selected sports soccer tech arts lifestyle fashion business travel environment browse all sections close opinion Money Money Opinion A cashless future? Sounds like a dream but don‚Äôt be fooled Gaby Hinsliff The head of Apple, Tim Cook, says all payments could soon be via smartphone apps. But there‚Äôs a sinister side to this vision, that would lead to us losing our freedom ‚ÄòEven for those who no longer believe in fairies, there‚Äôs something oddly magical about money.‚Äô Photograph: JGI/Jamie Grill/Getty Images/Blend Images Friday 21 October 2016 01.30¬†EDT Last modified on Friday 21 October 2016 03.24¬†EDT Share on Facebook Share on Twitter Share via Email Share on LinkedIn Share on Google+ Share on WhatsApp Share on Messenger The tooth fairy is dying. Soon, there will be no more scrabbling under pillows in the middle of the night; no more wondering what to do with a tiny molar, swapped for the traditional pound. (Chucking it in the bin seems heartless, keeping it faintly grisly.) But although my nine-year-old is reaching the limits of belief in fairies, it‚Äôs not just the magic that‚Äôs fading. It‚Äôs the habit of carrying cash. By 2025, three quarters of payments in Britain are expected to be made without notes or coins. We‚Äôre not quite Sweden ‚Äì where even street beggars are starting to take plastic, via card-readers handed out by charities ‚Äì but we‚Äôre moving in the same direction, towards a world of tapping contactless card to reader and paying by app, and who knows what else besides. Why cash isn't king any more Read more This week the former Barclays chief executive Antony Jenkins predicted the end of banks as we know them within two decades. What‚Äôs the point of these antiquated vaults, he suggested, when all that‚Äôs really needed to underpin the movement of wealth around the globe is a vast electronic ledger tracking who‚Äôs worth what, and some nifty apps for shunting it between us? So by the time my son grows up perhaps pound coins will be for ceremonial uses only, like silver sixpences stuffed in a Christmas pudding, and kids with gappy smiles will simply swipe left on the tooth fairy app. But I can‚Äôt help feeling we‚Äôll miss real money when it‚Äôs gone. For if cash is, as the saying goes, cold and hard then life without it may be more so. The under-30s increasingly seem to regard forking out actual coins as akin to bartering with seashells No more saving coppers in jars, dropping spare coins in charity boxes; no cash means no change, the end of that faint illusion of getting something back on the transaction. And the mind boggles at how men will mark their domestic territory, once they can‚Äôt leave small slagheaps of coins on every recently cleared surface in the house. But the bigger question here is who exactly a cashless society is designed to serve. Last week in Japan, Apple‚Äôs CEO, Tim Cook, once again spelled out the company‚Äôs aim to wean the world off cash, preferably in favour of using the Apple Pay app to buy everything via their smartphones. And while his airy insistence that ‚Äúwe don‚Äôt think the consumer particularly likes cash‚Äù might be true for the under-30s, who increasingly seem to regard forking out actual coins as akin to bartering with seashells, it should set alarm bells ringing for the rest of us. It‚Äôs not just that people tend to spend more freely when the money feels abstract, just numbers on a screen. Turn a phone into a virtual wallet, the one thing nobody leaves home without, and you‚Äôre shackled to it for ever. What was once an expensive toy becomes a necessity, a contract you can‚Äôt cancel if times get tough ‚Äì but also, perhaps, a tracking device. As any cheating spouse ever caught out by their credit card bill knows, paying with anything other than cash creates a trail, a record of transactions from which behaviour can be deduced. You don‚Äôt have to be a deranged conspiracy theorist to worry about the uses to which that information could one day be put, if not by authoritarian governments here or abroad, then by hackers. The freedom of cash isn‚Äôt something to be surrendered meekly or without thinking. But even if we don‚Äôt abandon the folding stuff altogether, the drift away from it has costs. The tooth fairy is not the only one at risk of redundancy. This summer, the last remaining bank branch in our nearest small market town closed down, which in retrospect was hardly surprising; every time I went in, invariably lugging bagfuls of change from school PTA fundraisers, there seemed to be fewer customers. In the last financial year more than 600 high street bank branches closed, which is bad news for the elderly and those who can‚Äôt travel, but even worse news for people working in them. Jobs in banking will go and they won‚Äôt be the kind of bankers everyone loves to hate but modestly paid counter and back-office staff, holding down what would once have been considered steady careers. Why we should fear a cashless world | Dominic Frisby Read more Automation has been eating away for years at one end of cash transaction, replacing shop assistants with machines, but is now coming for the other end: the places where cash is moved and managed. It‚Äôs not robots coming for these jobs, but apps that link buyer and seller or lender and borrower more directly, blowing up established professions in the middle. And while this world of fintech ‚Äì the point where finance meets technology, almost certainly to the bafflement of most of us ‚Äì should ultimately create jobs, they may not be the kind into which redundant bank cashiers can move seamlessly. Ah, say the prophets of plastic, but think of the problems a cash-free society solves: no more black markets in drugs or guns; fewer street muggers and cash-in-hand traders dodging tax. Really? This is surely not the end of crime, just the beginning of new ones, where hackers and fraudsters replace bank robbers and thieves, and new black markets emerge, using either virtual currencies such as bitcoin or whatever else comes to hand. (A few years ago a craze for shoplifting Tide detergent in the US was blamed, somewhat surreally, on addicts bartering the stuff for crack.) And for every would-be illegal immigrant deterred by the practical difficulties of surviving in a cash-free world, there will be homeless or otherwise marginalised Britons struggling to get by without smartphones and bank records. If we‚Äôre headed for a society where only the poor or the suspiciously shifty carry cash, it‚Äôs not hard to guess which outlets will carry on accepting their money and which will shut them out. You don‚Äôt have to pine for the days of bringing wages home in a brown paper packet to worry about whether a cashless future serves corporate interests rather better than social ones. Besides, even for those who no longer believe in fairies, there‚Äôs something oddly magical about money. Small enough to be slipped under a pillow or dropped in a busker‚Äôs hat, strong enough to be universally trusted, and foolproof enough to work even when your phone battery‚Äôs flat. Hang on to your cash. You never know when a rainy day is coming.
